projects.desc:
My World Works is a collection of maps that I've turned into interactive objects for individuals to analyze all kinds of nation-wide economic statistics. The complete scope of this project has proven to be much too large for one developer to manage but it has yielded an amazing foundation to build and maintain my skills in fullstack software and DevOps, as well as information and cyber security, all whilst also creating something with great future potential. In it's entirety, My World Works holds the structural capacity and promotes the architectural designs to store vast amounts of comprehensive, searchable data and create modestly detailed visualizations for over 140 different countries, and for each individual city where data is available. As someone who enjoys being abroad, I would love to be able to analyze a nation's econonomy in great detail, especially if I were to live and work from wherever that might be. In its current state, the app accomplishes just that, but for only 1 country, which I will explain further in just a moment! The inspiration behind this project is multi-faceted: I wanted to assist people who were seeking to optimize their work/life balance by enabling a visually comprehensisve comparison of cost-of-living data alongside very specific workforce statistics at varying levels of detail. Despite the app's pre-alpha state, users based in the USA can already make different discoveries such as where jobs are most available or most popular, and assuming my information from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (and several other sources) is reliable enough, this could improve an individual's sense of job security based on either the density or lack of certain metrics. With enough analysis, user's might be able to make their own inferences from the data. The reliability of the data would certainly improve over time with the right amount of management and marketing, but those ideas remain out of scope for the time being. With the help of Redis, querying large amounts of data remains relatively high-throughput and very performant as I've constructed a custom type-ahead search tree using the data structures and algorithms I learned early in my self-education; though I still have optimizations in mind. I eventually refactored the architecture so the app could bring similarly vast data-sets to all of the countries you'll find in the app. Each country has a complete data-set under the more general Economics feature (courtesy of The World Bank organization), but the USA remains my only complete data-set for even more useful features.

At the moment I have no intention to acquire the immeasurable amounts of missing data on my own. The data-sets are complete for the United States, which is a great milestone, and until I endeavor to put another country on the map, I am happy to hack away upon the architecure and systems I currently have in place. The scope is just too large for one developer but the app remains excellent sandbox, if not a potentially useful tool for some.

To fully demonstrate this app, you can choose The United States from the Economics tab, which enables the Work and Life tabs. The USA is the only country that currentlty activates those features, due to the reasons I've described above. Collecting reliable information on several different countries will be a very time consuming process, to say the least!

To prospect a little bit, once I've aggregated the necessary data for other nations, enabling the more highly detailed features boils down to a very simple update, so I am very excited to continue building and collecting data in the future. There are several challenges that reach beyond data collection and storage which one could imagine. The challenges ahead might surely bring this app to its full potential, and the nature those challenges cover a broad range of classifications. There are architectural and systematic designs which will assist in data collection and help to automate the generation and storage of aggregates, as well as researching even more effective means of its use. And there are also the more logistic and even bureaucratic tasks in terms of usage, validation and collection of data. If this app ever were to be used by a large number of users I would like to find a way to administer surveys to willing respondents who can help keep a country's economy as transparent and honest as possible. I truly think that a tool like this could help many people in many ways.
projects.caption: Demo for the Y-Combinator Summer 2021 application

projects.desc:
The Digital Toolbox is a learning management platform for k-12 mathematics, and is the epicenter of my longest-running role as a web developer. The app boasts 4 separate account types which can support a variety of users from private educators and homeschoolers to public and charter schools. They can create, manage and monitor virtual classrooms using Demme Learning's curricula. I orchestrated numerous upgrades, including the introduction of VueJS as the frontend framework, and introduced many useful applets including their worksheet generator, an open source Angular application that I repurposed to fit their curriculum materials. I also implemented Demme Learning's current Single Sign-On solution, as well as performed numerous Linux Administration tasks to keep their servers hardened and capable of adapting to increased server load and upgraded technologies.

I began working on this project as the sole developer of their team. Since then I've introduced modernizations to the underlying stack and have worked with outsourced teams of developers from all over the world to keep the Demme Learning domain evolving at a reasonable pace. I also build and maintain their administrative backend (a subdomain of the Digital Toolbox, but within the same Laravel project), which hosts custom tooling built by myself, which primarily supports customer service and accounting in their day to day tasks.
projects.caption: Just a peek at the cloud filesystem tool, built into the Toolbox's admin domain. Developed quite early in my career.

projects.desc: I've always been interested in 3D graphics, and over the years I've taken a few courses in mathematics to support this interest. I've developed 3 graphics pipelines, each with a different underlying API where I've taken my programming skills to the forefront of game development from scratch. I don't plan on building my own games just yet. For now these rendering engines keep me up to speed with the latest advancements in graphics APIs and allow me to utilize my linear algebra studies in a 3D context.
projects.caption: Part of an arcade series I'm working on.

title: Personal Space Invaders - Python Game with Sentiment Analysis

projects.desc: Personal space invaders started as a silly idea turned proof-of-concept. What began as a Python PyGame client has now turned into a React Native mobile app. This app accesses the Twitter API (v2) via AWS Lambda functions provisioned by the AWS Amplify CLI, (previously a Flask app in the cloud, hosted on Heroku. Compared to localized lambda support, this was very over-engineered but also a very basic solution for its time.) Sentiment analysis is then conducted upon the tweets of any valid Twitter handle, which determines the difficulty of the gameplay. The app proceeds to turn each tweet into a game of Space invaders where each tweet can be destroyed character by characters by the player.
projects.caption: Passing judgements upon our former president, programatically, so you don't have to.

projects.desc:
Doublevision is a sandbox for combining the artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities of OpenCV, with the GPIO capabilities of Arduino and Raspberry Pi. I've added the proper CMakeLists.txt in order to build your programs with a simple call to make. Also included is the ASIO header library to add networking to your projects.

What is most exciting about this project is that it uses a relatively new standard of interacting with the Raspberry Pi's GPIO interface, known as libgpio. This new lib deprecated the previous method of GPIO access by a longshot! Development can be done on any Raspberry Pi 3b+ or later.
projects.link: Check out the Doublevision repo on GitHub

projects.desc: This project allowed me to deep dive into both operating system design and embedded systems. Lyros is a multithreaded operating system from scratch that specifically targets the Texas-Instrument ARM Cortex-M series of microcontrollers.

title: Harvard CS50-AI
desc: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence with Python. This course taught me the concepts and algorithms at the foundation of modern artificial intelligence. I took my education in AI 1 step further and began using Jupyter Labs as a platform for which to practice ML concepts.

title: Harvard CS50
desc: Introduction to Computer Science. Taught by the mighty David Malan, Gordon McKay Professor of the Practice of Computer Science. This course was so amazing that I began taking it a 2nd time. I was a very active tutor on the CS50 reddit long after completion which subsequently prompted the creation of my WordPress blog.

title: Harvard CS50-B
desc: Computer Science for Business Professionals. Also taught by David Malan, this class focused more on the abstractions which computer science offers in your business domain. It covers everything from network architecure to cloud computing and security.

title: CompTIA A+ (2017 - 2021)
desc: Certifies general knowledge & practices in hardware, networking and software in the field of Information Technology.

title: CompTIA CySA+ (2018 - 2021)
desc: A much more involved certificate, the CySA+ demonstrates knowledge and practical skills in the fields of Cyber Forensics and Cyber Defense. Through this certification I have learned how to utilize many of the tools available in the Ethical Hacker's toolbelt.
